replies.commentBody: During his conformation hearing, Sessions wasn't asked if he had any contact whit Russian officials during the 2016 election. He was asked if he had had any meeting with Russians officials to discuss the 2016 election. He answered no. He maintains this is rue, and no one has presented any evidence to the contrary.

comments.commentBody:
"Then-Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) spoke twice last year with Russia’s ambassador to the United States, Justice Department officials said, encounters he did not disclose when asked about possible contacts between members of President Trump’s campaign and representatives of Moscow during Sessions’s confirmation hearing to become attorney general."

And this morning I heard the tape of the exchange between Sessions and Senator Al Franken wherein Sessions, referring to himself, said he had been referred to a number of time during the Trump campaign last year as a "surrogate" for Trump's campaign, said he, Sessions, had no personal knowledge of any meetings with the Russians.

Sessions could not possibly have forgotten one, let alone these two meetings with the Russians. Sessions lied to Senator Al Franken and the Senate and the American people. He should resign immediately.

It's no longer a question of "should he, Sessions, recuse himself" from the investigation. He lied during his confirmation hearing. He should resign or be Impeached. As Attorney General, he must be above any suspicion of misconduct. These two meetings with Russians, confirmed by the Justice Dept., are proof Sessions lied.

replies.commentBody:
I presume you are talking about bathroom issues in schools and gay marriage and other social issues. The Constitution guarantees all people will be treated equally under the law. Only when one part of the population tries to deny another the same rights as everyone else has is the Federal government obligated to step in.

No one says you have to marry if you are gay, but you also have no right to deny someone else that right. You don't have to have an abortion, but you have to allow others the right as it is the law (by the way, the fed gov't does not fund abortions unlike other healthcare services that are funded). I don't get the bathroom issue as anyone using a public washroom knows, it provides only limited privacy and if a person identifies as a woman is in a woman's washroom, well then it is only women in that washroom. To further wonder what all the fuss is about, I have never seen a naked person in a public washroom, I would use the stall if I wished to change.

comments.commentBody:
The refusal of former President Obama and his appointees and hires to relinquish power and abide by our Constitution ought to put real fear into the minds of all those who have been quaking with their manufactured hysteria about the lawful election of President Trump.

Obama promised to *transform* America and used his executive power to affect our society in ways that the majority of the population do not support.
He will do everything he can to obstruct the Trump administration and use his personality (as do most rulers with dictatorial instincts) to create chaos and riots.

We are seeing massive negative press coverage of President Trump which apparently originates from Obama acolytes in government.

The press is now obsessed with Russian but I can't recall similar interest when the Obama administration negligently permitted both Russia and China to hack government computer systems and obtain the personal data of tens of millions of Americans. That is a far greater threat than speaking to the Russian ambassador which everyone knows is a non event and accustomed practice for those in government.

It is very simple:
1) Russia stands to make a Trillion (yes, trillion, with a T) dollars via easier access to Siberia fossil fuels as a consequence of global warming. 2) The Trumpers stand to make a few billion via decreased environmental regulations and increased fossil fuels consumption.

Ergo the Russians want to assist Trump in his efforts to screw up the planet. For Putin, making the USA less safe is just a side benefit to the money.

The Trump administration is truly horrific for the USA and for the world.

Hmmm. So everyone here seems good with Obama directing intelligence to 'preserve' intelligence. We don't throw intelligence out.

What you're really saying is that he directed all intelligence resources to find intelligence against Trump. And not one cares about the fact that "The Obama administration has quietly funneled millions (and potentially billions) of dollars to leftist organizations and politicians that promote liberal policies and win political elections at the entry-level of government, according to the Wall Street Journal." http://dailycaller.com/2016/08/30/tens-of-millions-in-consumer-relief-fu...

Palestinian payoff?

Then there is the tax payer money he gave to OneVoice "Obama’s State Department gives OneVoice money. OneVoice trains student activists. Later, OneVoice strikes up a partnership with V15, which is aided by a former Obama campaign hand. V15, a voter mobilization project, wants to "disrupt the status quo." The status quo in this case is Netanyahu."

Then there is the slush fund..."findings from the House Judiciary Committee point to a process shrouded in secrecy where monies were distributed to a labyrinth of nonprofit organizations involved with grass-roots activism. “Advocates for big government and progressive power are using the Justice Department to extort money from corporations,” Judicial Watch’s Tom Fitton said. “It’s a shakedown. It’s corrupt, pure and simple.”

The ends do not justify means

replies.commentBody: Seems you believe there's a Russian Presence at the highest levels of our government and you want Obama(?) investigated and perhaps impeached for it?

comments.commentBody: Obama never changes. The cool facade masks a manipulative narcissist, who will do anything to exert and retain power and influence. Even after leaving the White House, he insinuates himself back onto the national stage through his back door use of intelligence gathered while he was president. The question remains for Democrats; if Obama had this evidence while he was president, why did he not share it with the American people while the presidential race was in full swing? Could it be he did not want Clinton to be president, and that he knew he could compromise the Trump presidency with the intelligence he refused to share with the American people at the time?  If so, it reveals a lot about a man who would be willing to sacrifice his own party and candidate for his own pleasure.

Many of the allegations in this article, if true, are stunning.  Particularly comments about "American intelligence picking up conversations in which Russian officials were discussing contacts with Trump associates" around the same time as the initial Wikileaks were occurring.  Also, around the same time, "European allies were starting to pass along information about people close to Mr. Trump meeting with Russians in the Netherlands, Britain and other countries."  And, as if that was not bad enough, evidence of attempts to engage in cyberattacks on state electoral systems in September.  Clearly, this needs to be investigated by a special counsel.  Further, this needs to be treated with utmost seriousness, not only with reference to its relationship with Trump, but with reference to future attempts that WILL happen when Russia attempts to engage in similar behavior.  We should be investigating and working to try to stop those future attempts NOW.

I never could put my head around how the Nixon Administration could be involved in the Watergate break in. This unfolded during my college and military service days. Thought Nixon was too smart to allow this to happen, no less cover it up.

The parallels now scare me, especially as Trump's ego and his "win at all cost" attitude has been proven to be corrosive. W recently said that power is corrosive and being President makes one powerful beyond what we " average Joes" can comprehend.

The Obama Administration's efforts described in the article may have been intended to spawn the next Deep Throat. Time will tell! What I don't understand is if damming information existed, why weren't the American people made aware of this before we voted. Such a situation fosters belief in the "tempest in a teapot" argument.

While many will dismiss "Russiagate" as the fancy of disillusioned HRC supporters or Newspapers intent on "getting even", conspiracy theorists now have something to convince them to put aside their focus on "man on the moon" investigations.

At a minimum we are in very scary times and Congress must get to the truth and quickly. This can only occur when a special prosecutor is appointed, one with full authority and access to all information, tax returns included.

My Senator Richard Burr is in a unique position to serve his country. He must put aside loyalty to his party and be loyal to the citizens of the United States. I call upon him to do the right thing!

By necessity the dots must be painstakingly connected and care must be taken that there is no possible error or possible misinterpretation or reinterpretation of facts here. That is the unbelievably hard job facing the intelligence community and the press right now. To borrow a phrase, Trust but Verify seems the most prudent course of action for reading the published parts of this mind bending and unrelenting coverage of Russian meddling in the U.S. government, election, press and who knows what else. Patience has never been more vital and important. In the end it will all come right. It must. It simply must.

We are still in the information gathering stage.  That being said, it is imperative that as much information be gathered so that informed, objective decisions can be made.  This information must include that which will expose President Trump's true relationship with Russia.  This must begin with his past business dealings.  This should begin with his tax returns.  It is time they are reviewed either with or without his permission.

Does anyone really think this will receive the proper investigation it should with the Republicans in charge? Will any investigation even begin with a demand that Trump release his tax returns? All of this is beginning to rise to treason, yet there are only a few Republicans who will even state that Sessions should recuse himself from any investigation for starters. Convenient that Sessions is now AG. What more does anyone need to understand that Trump aides were meeting with the Russians prior to the election, with some reason in mind? We already knew about Paul Manafort's ties to Russian politicians, it doesn't take a genius to look at the meetings between Trump's aides and other Russians and conclude the meetings had some political purpose.
If I had to venture a guess, it would be that Trump himself did not have direct contact with the Russians. Any negotiating was most likely done through surrogates to either suppress damaging information the Russians had on Trump, either personal or financial, or seeking help through hacking to pervert the outcome of the election, or both. As usual, the first thing from the Trump camp says is all of this is false. Trust is a fragile thing, and I have none right for Trump or anyone connected with him, then again, I never did, this only further deepens my mistrust. I suspect if there is any investigation, a report will not be forthcoming until after 2018.

Russian contact during election season or even after the presidency - is the administration keeping silent to prove legitimacy of such interactions? Inspite of so much humality in the public and the media why is the administration not coming out clean? Lies after lies, humality after humality, alternate facts after alternate facts, false statements after false statements - what else we need to preserve the dignity of all individuals who are leading the country and us? The prestige of the office cannot be preserved under such shadowy environment. should we urge our patriot senators and congressmen to answer to the cause of bipartisan actions so that our democracy survive?

I do not agree with several readers who posted that President Obama should not be blamed for failure to disclose the strong indications that the Russian government was actively interfering with our upcoming election.

I understand that he did not want to appear like he was influencing the election, but his tendency to lean out and be on the side of political caution was a mistake, just like it was when he had the chance in 2010 to push through a single-payer health care system and retreated. Or when he pulled back from that famous red line in the sand in Syria.

At the time this information about Russia came to his attention, he and every other Democrat (as well as many Republicans) thought Hillary Clinton was a shoe-in for the presidency. You can't tell me that this did not color his decision to keep the info under wraps.

Cautious political chess moves? Sure, right out of the Election 101 playbook. But with all the information coming in that kept hitting the Clinton campaign right where it hurts - FBI Director Comey's letter, the Wiki Leaks leaks, Trump playing down and dirty in the debates - Obama should have rolled the dice and made the information public, appointed an independent prosecutor and let the chips fall where they may.

We will never know if the outcome of the election would have changed had he done that, but I would bet the farm that it would have raised enough of a cloud over Donald Trump to sway voters on the fence to vote for Clinton.

It is axiomatic that more political fallout will follow a cover up than a contrite  admission of guilt. Yet, the current Administration seems incapable of critical self examination.  By claiming credit but not responsibility the trend would suggest their continued denial of any interaction with the Russians. The more they dissemble the deeper the hole they dig. As facts arise that show even incidental contact they undercut their own defense. At some point all but the most rabid ideologues will want to put partisanship aside and demand a thorough accounting. Sunlight is the best disinfectant.

The time is now to start an open congressional inquiry.  Trump has successfully cast enough doubt on the veracity of stories like this so that  many Americans have become dismissive of it.  Trump is a master at repeating outright lies and consistently accusing the press of playing dirty and spitefully, to a point where you actually start to believe him.  As a result, the mountain of evidence from unnamed sources has become increasingly dubious, or certainly the incremental information has.  Only an open inquiry can come to a conclusion that is credible and acceptable to the American public.  And if Sessions is found in the process to have lied, he can then be recused - or worse.

I am sure that the intelligence groups were concerned about the Trump administration "disappearing" information about the Russian connection, since it could incriminate a bunch of people, and would reveal sources and methods  that Trump would out to the Russians.  I say this because I believed that once Trump got into office the intelligence that would incriminate him that evidence would disappear. Trump puts himself above the country every time, and I believe he would gladly out any intelligence officer foreign or domestic to keep his secrets and to cover up any wrongdoing. I also believe that he would turn over any methods we use to gather intelligence to Putin. So the dispersement of intelligence to various entities was prudent and smart of those in the Obama administration. I would bet anything that any information given to the Trump administration has not been preserved as directed by law. The Obama administration were protecting the country and its foreign allies who the Russians are using the same tactics on to interfere in their upcoming elections.  The truth of the Russian collusion with the Trump campaign in our election is important, as well as the examination of Russia's act of war on us with  its cyber attack.

replies.commentBody: Session's may not have perjured himself, in the same way Bill Clinton didn't perjure himself when he was impeached on that charge. That is, in a court of law, with some clever manipulation of the prosecution, Sessions might get away with explaining the situation away. That's what I call "little" truth. As "big" truth, or Truth, we all know the real deal with Clinton. And we all know the real deal with Sessions.

Sessions'  work as a US Senator went on, even as he was advising Donald Trump.    He was wearing two different hats!   Wasn't it YOUR SIDE who emphasized the ability to "compartmentalize" ala Bill Clinton, who could lie and cheat with impunity while "president?"

comments.commentBody: If Jeff Sessions' discussions with Russian contacts weren't treasonous, why did he choose to perjure himself in his confirmation hearing to cover them up?  This, from our nation's top law enforcement official. Pathetic.

I do not know nor pretend to know what transgressed or didn't transgress among or between the Russian government representatives and the Trump Campaign officials. Long and short, I have no first or fifth hand knowledge of these activities or non-activities. But I do know there is a font of information that is not public and wishes to remain not public. Until this information sees the light of public disclosure and discourse, I remain suspicious. It is in the Administration's best interest to allow full disclosure unless there is a there in their there.
I am an independent voter and I do listen to and weigh all sides. My skin in the game is: I am an American and the daughter of a Normandy Invasion naval recruit. Samuel S. Case. Pharmacy Mate. Please tell me that these men did not suffer in vain. My Dad suffered the rest of his life from the experience of that day. And he passed on his suffering to his 5 children. Such are the invoices of war and terror.

In these situations, the cover up just leads to more cover up, and the eventual truth will always come out. Trump is clearly embroiled in something unpleasant that he feels determined to deny (and once it is glaring at him, watch how fast he changes his demeanor from his Tuesday night so-called "Presidential" speech.) I now feel confident that this will not go away, that Trump and his administration will have to face the truth and the consequences. On the other hand, impeachment probably won't solve the problem, as Pence and the remainder of the administration (presumably corrupt) would then take over. I don't know what procedure is in place for this kind of radical dilemma in government, but I hope there are enough sane Republicans willing to condemn this to the end.

replies.commentBody: Add to the list the recent revelations (or rather the confirmation of what many people already knew) of then candidate Richard Nixon's sabotage of the Johnson administration's peace negotiations to end the war Vietnam.  A party, led by people, so devoid of morality and patriotism is unfit to exercise even limited political power.

comments.commentBody: Iran-Contra, Uranium forgeries in Niger, Russian hacking...35 years of GOP corruption and treachery. At what point are we going to stop voting this party into power?

replies.commentBody: You'll get the same hostile 'results' if  you check the coverage of Anthony Weiner, Osama Bin Laden, and Dylann Roof. Isn't it a pain, when non-Breitbart media have an ethical standard!

comments.commentBody:
No surprise to anyone with a mind of their own:
There was no press honeymoon for President Trump during his first month in office. A meticulous new study by the Media Research Center finds that 88 percent of the broadcast news coverage of Mr. Trump and his team was “hostile” during the first 30 days of office.
“Further highlighting the hostile tone of these newscasts, nearly an hour of coverage (56 minutes) was given over to anti-Trump protests on various topics, with nearly one-fifth (82 out of 442) of the Trump stories or briefs aired during these 30 days including at least some discussion of an anti-Trump protest,” Mr. Noyes reported.
Mr. Trump may be accustomed to the treatment by now, however. A previous Media Research Center report found that 91 percent of the broadcast coverage about his campaign was also negative.

Influencing foreign elections through propaganda is nothing new for the U.S. or Russia. We may not like that our citizenry is susceptible to these types of efforts, but propaganda is not ballot box tampering. Without evidence that vote tallies were directly altered, there is nothing to do except be disappointed.

The primary question should be, if evidence of ballot box tampering did exist, could it be revealed and acted upon? I'll hypothesize that such evidence does exist, and that those in possession of that evidence made the decision not to act. That admitting the election process is flawed would be more damaging than letting a reality show host serve as the so-called president.

Congress must instruct the IRS to release Trump's COMPLETE tax returns for the last 10 years (at least) due to the cloud of treason. Trump should be happy to release them to clear his name. If not, he has something serious to hide and impeachment proceedings should begin.

The Russia distraction attempts to hide the fact that the presidential election in 2016 was was hacked. Unfortunately, it was by the good guys, not the GOP. That fact was revealed by WikiLeaks. Communication between the DNC, Clinton campaign, and media illuminati made it clear they were colluding to thwart Mr. Sanders (beginning long before the votes were cast).

According to Mr. Assange, WikiLeaks apprehended the emails from a non-Russian source. The hacker didn't require sophisticated nation-state tools nor the kind expertise we have in the NSA because the Clinton, DNC, and Podesta emails were minimally protected. Apparently, they would have been vulnerable to a fist-year computer science student without a date on Saturday night.

If the stakes are as high as these stories portend, shouldn't a way be found to support and protect unnamed sources willing to come out publicly for the good of the country?

Just re watched "All The President's Men" last week. The story of Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward receiving the story of a break in to the DNC at the Watergate Hotel Offices. The story of course was much deeper and it was the exhaustive and courageous work of these tenacious journalists which uncovered a conspiracy which involved all branches of government all the way to the White House. This story which is being uncovered these past few weeks is a breach in our government which does in fact threaten our very democracy. This story is only in its infancy but we know that it encompasses far more than a break in and cover up. We already know that European intelligence from multiple countries provided information to our White House and that the outgoing President provided to the Congress the information before him in an unprecedented effort toward protecting vital information about our enemies in collusion with the incoming President. The integrity of our democracy is at risk. I was in high school when Watergate broke and we all knew the significance at that moment in our history. Today, we live in a time which is precarious and you cannot underestimate what is happening right now. Make no mistake that the events which happened in 2016 will require an independent prosecutor and will take this administration down. It will become a major piece of our history and we are all witnessing it.

" ... political appointees in the Obama administration have sought to create a false narrative to make an excuse for their own defeat in the election.”

Spicey, it's time to drop the sour-grapes talking point and starting writing a new script. Here's a real-life example you can use as a template:

"I think we would all have to say, and I would be, I think, remiss if I did not say, that mistakes were made during this period in terms of comments that were made, perhaps. I would say that I was overenthusiastic at the time in my comments about The Post, particularly if you look at it in the context of the developments that have taken place. In thinking of it at this point in time, yes, I would apologize to The Post. . . . When we're wrong, we're wrong.''

--Ron Ziegler, Nixon Administration, on whether he would apologize for characterizing The Washington Post's coverage of the Watergate story as ''shabby journalism'' and ''character assassination.''
